resource.name: Crown Land
resource.description:
A spatial dataset of all Crown lands in Nova Scotia. Crown lands are all or any part of the land under the administration and control of the Minister of Natural Resources and Renewables as per the Crown Lands Act. The dataset includes land in which the Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources and Renewables has full or partial interest.
Data download also available via GeoNova: https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/WSF_DDS/DDS.svc/DownloadFile?tkey=fhrTtdnDvfytwLz6&id=87
Map service view also available via GeoNova: https://www.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnsgiwa.novascotia.ca%2Farcgis%2Frest%2Fservices%2FPLAN%2FPLANCrownLandsWM84V1%2FMapServer&source=sd

resource.name: Municipal Property Tax Rates
resource.description: The dataset is a list of property tax rates that are applicable in each municipality in the Province. These rates are applied to property assessment (based on market value) which can change from year to year. The convention is to express the tax rate as per $100 of assessment e.g., Amherst's residential rate is $1.63 per $100 of assessment.

domain_metadata.value: This information has been gathered from Statement of Estimate Reports as submitted to the Province by municipalities. The municipalities are required to submit this informaiton to the Province by Sepember 30th of each year.  Municipalities may also have additional area rates for special services on top of the general rate. Users are cautioned these tax rates are for general reference only, for official rates please contact the appropriate Municipality.   The Cape Breton Suburban rate is an average of 8 various rural suburban tax rates within the county of Cape Breton.    Effective April 1st, 2020, the Town of Windsor and the Municipality of West Hants have consolidated into a regional municipality, West Hants Regional Municipality.
Annually from each fiscal year, from 09-10 to 22-23 (April 1, 2009 to March 31, 2023)

resource.name: Gaelic Placenames in Nova Scotia
resource.description: Gaelic placenames in Nova Scotia contain placenames Nova Scotia Gaels have for communities in Pictou, Antigonish, Guysborough, Inverness, Victoria, Richmond and the Cape Breton Regional Municipality

domain_metadata.value: Current as of May 22, 2019 with the addition of geolocation data. The Gaelic Place Names dataset does not contain official names for Nova Scotia but intended to enrich cultural awareness and for general reference use only. Official place names are maintained by Geographic Information Services in the Department of Internal Services through the Nova Scotia Geographic Names Program. To search for officially approved geographical names of Nova Scotia, please refer to the GeoNAMES Explorer application at GeoNOVA.ca

resource.name: Shelburne County Wave Data
resource.description: Wave time series data collected at various locations throughout the waters of Shelburne County by the Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture’s Aquaculture Division.
columns_description: The average value of all valid readings of the direction from which the wave is travelling (in degrees relative to true north), recorded across all bins over the course of the ensemble, where applicable
Period (seconds) of the largest wave, where applicable
Peak wave period (seconds), where applicable
Mean height (meters) of the highest 1/3rd of waves, where applicable
Averaged distance (meters) between the sensing face of the recording instrument and the ocean surface over the course of the ensemble, where applicable
Consolidated date and time stamp of when the ensemble was recorded
Day of the month during which the ensemble was recorded
Month during which the ensemble was recorded
Peak wave direction from which the wave is travelling (in degrees relative to true north) at the peak period, where applicable
Maximum wave height (meters)
Mean height (meters) of the highest 1/10th of waves, where applicable
Second during which the ensemble was recorded
Hour of the day during which the ensemble was recorded, 0 to 23
Sequential count of averaged profile readings taken over the course of the deployment
Waterbody into which the instrument was deployed
Unique identifier assigned to each deployment
Average wave period (seconds) of top 1/10th largest waves, where applicable
Significant wave height (meters)
Average wave period (seconds) of top 1/3rd largest waves, where applicable
Minute of the hour during which the ensemble was recorded
Year during which the ensemble was recorded

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates. The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

resource.name: Halifax County Water Quality Data
resource.description: Oceanographic data from sensor strings deployed in Halifax County as part of the Centre for Marine Applied Research's (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program.
columns_description: the deployment and retrieval dates
longitude at which the string was deployed (decimal degrees)
waterbody in which the string was deployed
indicates whether the string was attached to a fixed (does not move vertically with the tide) or floating mooring
timestamp of the measurement (in UTC)
parameter measured (Temperature, Dissolved Oxygen, or Salinity)
latitude at which the string was deployed (decimal degrees)
if the string was deployed on an aquaculture lease area, the lease number (NA otherwise)
approximate depth of the sensor below the surface in metres (as measured at low tide for fixed moorings)
value of the measurement (units are noted in UNITS column)
model and serial number of the sensor that recorded the measurement
the unit of measurement for corresponding VALUE
area where the string was deployed

domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Halifax-County-Daily-Av/vpt7-apvp) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Halifax County (https://cmar.ca/reports/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Halifax-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-Va/vpt7-apvp). Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/reports/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated O

resource.name: Average Daily Counts at Adult and Youth Correctional Facilities
resource.description: Average daily count statistics of adults and youth in custody are derived from daily count statistics of adults and youth incarcerated in adult or youth correctional facilities in Nova Scotia. The average daily count is submitted to Statistics Canada and data is published for the provinces and territories on an annual basis through their Key Indicators Report (KIR) survey and CANSIM. Due to the time lag in publishing the data by Statistics Canada, however, data for the most recent year is provided by the Nova Scotia Department of Justice.

domain_metadata.value: CANSIM Table 251-0005 Adult correctional services, average counts of offenders in provincial and territorial programs (http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/a26?lang=eng&id=2510005), CANSIM 251-0008 Youth correctional services, average counts of young persons in provincial and territorial correctional services (http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/a26?lang=eng&id=2510008), and Corrections in Nova Scotia: Key Indicators (http://novascotia.ca/just/publications/docs/2015-16_CORRECTIONS_KEY_INDICATOR_REPORT.pdf)

Current as of June, 2021. For the youth counts, the other category includes Provincial Director Remand. For the adult counts, the other category includes: new federal, federal for court, federal/provincial transfers, parole suspensions and immigration.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Topographic Database - Land Cover (Poly)
resource.description:
Part of the Nova Scotia Topographic Database (NSTDB), the land cover theme layer is updated and maintained from aerial photography. Land cover is limited to treed areas over 3600m2 in size and over two metres in height. Orchards, nurseries, tree lines, and single landmark trees are also included. Land Cover feature codes and their descriptions are provided with
the download in a NSTDB feature code table.

resource.description:
The Nova Scotia GeoNAMES dataset contains all current approved and offical geographic names for the Province of Nova Scotia. The named features in the dataset include Populated Places, Administrative Areas, Water and Terrain Features, Vegetation Areas, some Manmade Features, and Undersea Features.
Geographic names in the Province of Nova Scotia are approved by the province's representative on the Geographical Names Board of Canada.

resource.name: "Book of Negroes", 1783
resource.description: The "Book of Negroes" is the single most important document relating to the immigration of African Americans to Nova Scotia following the War of Independence. It provides the names of 3000 black refugees registered on board the vessels in which they sailed from New York to Nova Scotia between 23 April and 30 November 1783.

resource.name: Number of People Represented by Nominee Certificates
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills, and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Certificates are issued in particular streams of the Nominee Program, and each stream has different eligibility criteria. Over time, streams may close as new streams are developed. 

This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by the streams under which the nomination was made and the number of people expected to immigrate to Nova Scotia as a result of nominations in each stream.

See https://novascotiaimmigration.com/move-here/ for information on current streams.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of May 5, 2023. A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

resource.name: Agricultural Land Protection
resource.description:
This dataset provides information about how agricultural land is being protected through municipal land use planning. Each municipality is listed along with the level of agricultural land protection found within municipal land use plans. Agricultural protection is described as either exclusive zoning for agricultural land, agriculture identified as permitted use, or no planning for agriculture. 

Assessment of Agricultural Protection
Municipal planning strategies and land-use by-laws were assessed to determine the level of protection being given to agricultural land in the province. 
Three levels of protection have been identified through the planning document review:
1) Exclusive zoning for agricultural land meaning that agricultural land is identified and given a specific zoning with the intent of protecting agricultural land, activities and resources. 
2) Agriculture identified as a permitted use in other zones (rural residential, rural resource/development,industrial etc). Many of these zones have restrictions on certain agricultural uses, such as intensive livestock operations.
3) No planning for agriculture identifies municipalities that either do not have comprehensive municipal planning strategies or do not explicitly identify agriculture or agricultural activities within their planning strategies and land use bylaws.

domain_metadata.value: Data is a result of a scan done by Provincial planning employees but has not been vetted by the Municipalities.

resource.name: Victoria County Current Data
resource.description: Current speed and direction time series data collected in a vertical profile at various locations throughout the coastal waters of Victoria County.
columns_description: the depth of the ADCP below the surface (metres), measured by the ADCP sensor. Changes with the tide.
specific area where ADCP was deployed.

direction of water flow for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (degrees). Measured travelling away from the ADCP sensor relative to True North (a reading of 90 degrees describes current travelling from west to east).
water speed for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (m / s).
distance from the seafloor to the centre of the measurement bin (metres).

distance from the surface to the centre of the measurement bin (metres). Calculated as sensor_depth_below_surface_m + sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m - bin_height_above_sea_floor_m. See “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) for sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m.

timestamp of the start of the ensemble (in UTC). Current speed and direction recorded at each timestamp are an average of many measurements recoded during the ensemble. See the “Nova Scotia Current Data Deployment Information” dataset for ensemble details for each deployment.
waterbody in which the ADCP was deployed.

unique identifier for ADCP deployment. IDs are assigned incrementally by deployment date within a county. A skipped ID (e.g., consecutive IDs are XY001 and XY003) indicates that an ADCP was deployed but no useable current data were recovered (e.g., the battery failed).

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/9f4x-q35z).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.c

resource.name: Early Years Centres (EYC) Contact Information
resource.description: Contact Information: Early Years Centres

resource.name: Atlantic Quarterly Autumn 2017 Tobacco and E-cigarette Use
resource.description: Data set is results of commissioned questions the Atlantic Quarterly omnibus public opinion survey conducted in November 2017.  The questions relate to public opinion and behaviour regarding “underground economy” (purchasing contraband tobacco) and tobacco and ecigarette use.  Overall results are provided for each question and results are presented by demographic markers (age, gender, geographic region, education level and household income).

resource.name: Nova Scotia Culture Survey 2022
resource.description: The Nova Scotia Culture Survey was conducted between March 2 - 21, 2022. 1,000 Nova Scotia residents aged 18+ were surveyed using telephone interviews. The survey measured Nova Scotian's attitudes about culture and their cultural identities.

domain_metadata.value: The data consists of responses from 1,000 Nova Scotia residents aged 18+, surveyed between March 2— 21, 2022. It was collected using random telephone interviews. Margin of error +/- 3.1 %, 19/20 times. The fields are text or numeric.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Topographic DataBase - Utilities (Line Layer)
resource.description:
Part of the Nova Scotia Topographic Database (NSTDB), the utilities theme layer is updated and maintained from aerial photography, and verified with field inspections. Pipelines, Tanks and electrical substations are collected among other types of features. Utility feature codes and their descriptions are provided with the download in a NSTDB feature code table.
Data download also available via GeoNova: https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/WSF_DDS/DDS.svc/DownloadFile?tkey=fhrTtdnDvfytwLz6&id=17
Map service view also available via GeoNova: https://nsgiwa.novascotia.ca/arcgis/rest/services/BASE/BASE_NSTDB_10k_Utilities_UT83/MapServer?f=jsapi

domain_metadata.value: For additional information on the dataset, see: 1. https://www.nsgc.gov.ns.ca/mappingspecs/Specifications/Compilation/Resource_NSTDB/default.htm ; 2. the Topographic 1:10,000 digital index https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/datalocator/indexing/ (use the identify tool within the application to click on individual mapsheets to view); 3. index web map service that labels the 1:10,000 index, showing the year of photography used to update each mapsheet https://nsgiwa.novascotia.ca/arcgis/rest/services/BASE/BASE_Index_NSTDB_10k_WM84/MapServer
Lower Left Extent = N 43°00', E -66° 30', Upper Right Extent = N 47° 30', -59°00' UTM NAD83 (CSRS)

resource.name: [ARCHIVED] Census Long Form Citizenship and Immigration
resource.description: [ARCHIVED] Community Counts data is retained for archival purposes only, such as research, reference and record-keeping. This data has not been maintained or updated. Users looking for the latest information should refer to Statistics Canada’s Census Program (https://www12.statcan.gc.ca/census-recensement/index-eng.cfm?MM=1) for the latest data, including detailed results about Nova Scotia. This table reports where residents were born. This data is sourced from the Census of Population (long form). Geographies available: provinces, counties, communities, municipalities, district health authorities, community health boards, economic regions, police districts, school boards, school areas, municipal electoral districts, provincial electoral districts, federal electoral districts, regional development authorities, watersheds

1:10,000 watersheds for Nova Scotia. Contains secondary watersheds.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Landbased Aquaculture Licenses
resource.description: The Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture is the lead regulatory of aquaculture leasing and licensing.  This file illustrates all the issued landbased licenses within Nova Scotia. Fisheries and Aquaculture also provides a mapping tool for this data at: http://novascotia.ca/fish/aquaculture/site-mapping-tool/

domain_metadata.value: Given the fact there are daily updates to this file, please contact the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture for the most up-to-date information. The primary software for opening this file is ArcGIS and associated extensions. This file is not to be used for legal purposes or navigation. Nova Scotia Fisheries & Aquaculture accepts no liability for any errors, deficiencies or omissions in this file.
Served through the Nova Scotia Geospatial Infrastucture

resource.name: Nova Scotia Topographic DataBase - Landforms (Spot Point Layer)
resource.description:
Part of the Nova Scotia Topographic Database (NSTDB), the landforms theme layer is updated and maintained from aerial photography. Contours, spot elevations, Cut/fill locations along roadways, as well as cliffs and embankments are collected. Landform feature codes and their descriptions are provided with the download in a NSTDB feature code table.
Data download also available via GeoNova: https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/WSF_DDS/DDS.svc/DownloadFile?tkey=fhrTtdnDvfytwLz6&id=14
Map service view also available via GeoNova: https://nsgiwa.novascotia.ca/arcgis/rest/services/BASE/BASE_NSTDB_10k_Landforms_UT83/MapServer?f=jsapi
